page.title: 07ANDREW CROSSE
page.content: Born at Fyne Court, Broomfield in 1784 He went to school in Bristol and then to Brasenose College, Oxford. He came back to live at Fyne Court. While still young he became interested in electrical science and technology and studied electricity, chemistry and mineralogy. In 1807 he experimented with crystals and electricity and put up 1.25 miles of insulated copper wire for other experiments. In 1836 at a meeting of the British Association in Bristol he met scientists and talked about his experiments with batteries. He became recognised as an important scientist himself. Later he discovered that insects seemed to be formed in experiments, which made him unpopular and gave a novelist the idea of FRANKENSTEIN.
